previous_statement: Very good reporting. I remember this was unfolding before the Winter Olympic Games, about 30,000 U.S. troops on the ground in South Korea right now. Jeremy Diamond, thank you very much. More breaking news. A federal judge here in Washington has just rejected former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort's attempt to dismiss special counsel Robert Mueller's criminal case against him. Our justice correspondent, Evan Perez, has been working the story for us. Evan, Manafort says Mueller's probe has overstepped its legal authority. The judge disagrees.
statement: That's right. Wolf, the federal judge, Amy Berman Jackson, says that Manafort's claims that the special counsel's overstepped his bounds are completely without merit. She says that Paul Manafort <SHOULD> prepare to go on trial in September here in Washington. Remember, he's facing charges both here and -- both here in Washington and in Northern Virginia. And let me read to you <A LITTLE> bit of what Judge Amy Berman Jackson had to say <ABOUT> this. She said: "Who had connections to the Russian government? Who attended meetings on behalf of the campaign? Given the combination of his prominence within the campaign and his ties to Ukrainian officials supported by him operating out of Russia, as <WELL> as to Russian oligarchs, Manafort was an obvious person of interest. The special counsel <WOULD> have been remiss to ignore such an obvious potential link between the Trump campaign and the Russian government." Look, Wolf, this case has garnered a lot of criticism of the special counsel, simply because it predates a lot of the campaign. It has nothing to do, per se, with the Russian government. Manafort's lawyers and some of the president's supporters have pointed out that, you know, there's no allegation in here of him directly in contact with people from -- with people associated with the Russian government. The special counsel counters that by saying that he was working for the Ukrainians, for Ukrainian interests, some of which had ties to the Russian government, people who were working as undercover spies, so to speak, for the Russian government. Again, he's facing trial here in Washington in September. A judge in Virginia is going to hear similar -- is hearing similar requests from Manafort to dismiss those charges. He's scheduled for trial there in July. Manafort has pleaded not guilty in both courts on these trials -- on these cases -- on these charges.
